Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: The American Society for Engineering Education (ASEE) is organizing and coordinating the logistics for the 2013 and 2014 Grantees Meetings of the STEM Talent Expansion Program (STEP). These annual meetings bring together Principal Investigator (PI) teams for all STEP projects to exchange ideas, to share progress reports and information about proven practices, and to examine, collectively, issues of STEM retention and degree attainment. The intellectual merit of this project lies in its "meta-level" examination of the general benefits of such community building activities in furthering the aims of the STEP program. For example, the project team is assessing the impact of the content and logistics of the STEP Grantees meeting on program objectives such as: i) increasing awareness of promising practices and promoting their adaptation and use; ii) building and sustaining communities of interest (among faculty, administrators, and community leaders) able to implement, refine, and innovate promising practices; and iii) catalyzing wide-scale action toward undergraduate STEM education innovation by communities of interest that transform into communities of practice beyond individual departments or campuses. Simultaneously, the project is exercising broad impact by identifying strategies that enhance the widespread use of the most effective education practices, which in turn inform efforts to strengthen the robustness of the Nation's STEM workforce and lay the foundation for its global competitiveness.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The National Science Foundation (NSF) is the federal government’s primary entity for funding academic research in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM). NSF also seeks opportunities to bolster the STEM workforce, helping to guarantee US competitiveness in these fields and strengthen national security. Given this charge, NSF’s STEM Talent Expansion Program (STEP) seeks to increase the number of students receiving associate’s or bachelor’s degrees in established or emerging STEM fields.

Because STEP grantees often work in silos from other people involved with STEP-funded activities, there is limited ability to share best practices, learn from mistakes and successes at other institutions, and build working relationships. The STEP grantees meetings hosted by ASEE brought together faculty, administrators, student support specialists, and evaluators involved in in STEP-funded projects to create an opportunity for knowledge sharing and collaboration.

The primary goals of these meetings were to:

  • Increase awareness of promising practices
  • Promote the adaptation and use of promising practices
  • Build and sustain communities of interest (among faculty, administrators, and community leaders) who are able to implement, refine, and innovate promising practices
  • Catalyze wide-scale action toward undergraduate STEM education innovation by communities of interest that evolve into communities of practice beyond individual departments or campuses

The meetings were comprised of several core activities: breakout sessions, plenary sessions, poster sessions, and informal networking opportunities. The breakout sessions explored various topics, including evaluation, project management, data collection and organization, and undergraduate research. NSF staff representatives were present at these sessions to offer insights and respond to grantee inquiries. Through these sessions, several common challenges emerged, as voiced by grantees: revolving personnel at the administrative level; instituting peer mentoring; and problems external to the grantee’s organization (e.g. poor math skills among incoming students).

The plenary sessions featured STEM education leaders who presented a “30,000-foot” view of the needs of both STEM students and the institutions seeking to offer quality STEM instruction. The poster sessions showcased more than 100 grantee posters, providing yet another opportunity for information and knowledge sharing. Informal networking opportunities further allowed grantees to interact and talk about their programs, challenges, and successes.

STEP Central, a virtual community of practice, was created as part of this project, allowing participants to continue conversations started at the meetings and giving them a repository to share and find relevant information. Through this online tool, research on best practices for sustaining STEP grant activities after NSF funding ends was conducted and disseminated. Through partnering with the American Association of Colleges and Universities (AAC&U) and with the American Society of Engineering Education (ASEE), STEP Central evolved into STEM Central (https://stem-central.net), a more robust and sustainable resource that seeks to reach the broader undergraduate STEM education community.

Additionally, in line with the goal of spreading the exchange of ideas and promising practices that support STEP grants, research was conducted to identify practices that help to sustain and institutionalize STEP grant activities after grant funding has ended. Our research activities included the distribution of an online survey to STEP Principal Investigators (PIs) and co-Principal Investigators, the study of an online focus group comprised of STEP PIs and co-PIs, and the development of a rubric that evaluates institutionalization planning in STEP grant applications.

Through our research, we learned that certain practices can help to sustain and institutionalize STEP activities after grant funding ends. These practices include:

  1. Developing an institution-wide communication plan
  2. Gathering data that shows the success of grant activities and documents the institutionalization of program activities
  3. Engaging grant stakeholders in project implementation
  4. Engaging administrators in the project

Additionally, our research indicated that PIs and co-PIs were better able to sustain grant activities that they, as faculty members, had the most influence over. These activities include increased faculty-student mentoring, peer mentoring programs, implementing new teaching methods and increasing faculty time with students to enhance student learning. Less frequently sustained activities were those that required coordination and resources from the university beyond the PI’s department, like student advising programs led by university staff and Teaching Assistant (TA) training.   

Our research findings were disseminated through a technical report and a professional development workshop held at the 2018 ASEE Annual Conference and Exposition in Salt Lake City, UT. Through our research, we have come to view sustainability and institutionalization as concepts that can be taught to PIs and co-PIs. Additional studies are needed to better understand the dynamics of the institutionalization of project activities after funding ends. Furthermore, there is a need for resources and training opportunities that can increase PI and co-PI awareness of best practices for sustaining grant activities after NSF funding ends, so they have the knowledge and tools to successfully apply these practices at their own institutions.
